text: I'm Seth kugel the frugal traveler for
the New York Times this summer I'm
spending 13 weeks going from Brazil to
New York City
my latest stop Colombia a country all
too often overlooked by Globetrotters
I've slept in colonial towns dance salsa
and gasped at dramatic landscapes but
despite the color Colombia's not so
distant past still stirs fear for some
tourists or at least their mothers I
think at one point when I first told her
she said to me John if you're having if
serious men with guns are talking to you
don't kid around my first stop was
Sylvia in southwestern Colombia which I
found to be quite safe fear the
indigenous WOM beyond OHS retain their
language and traditional dress on market
day they come down from the hills in
colorful Chiba buses it wasn't long ago
that Sylvia was touched by Colombia's
guerrilla war Antonio Fernandez
remembers the bad old days when the
guerrillas came to Sylvia 12 years ago
they destroyed the bank here on the
corner bad idea
but most people agree Sylvia is now safe
next I was off to the college city of
Papa Yan where I wandered through the
fine arts campus of prestigious calcio
University I was mesmerized by the
city's gorgeous colonial setting in 2005
Papa Yan was named city of gastronomy by
UNESCO for creations like the sweets
aletheia Ortiz sells for pennies apiece
guests residence this is a family
tradition my mother started and I'm
carrying on one last at you then I was
off to see the archeological treasures
of San Augustin dozens of volcanic rock
statues are among the only clues left to
a mysterious civilization that
disappeared about 1,500 years ago the
best way to see son Augustine is on a
horse if you can get up on them it
wasn't so easy
our guide Pacho like so many Colombians
is frustrated with his country's
notoriety porque la cr√©me chief around
the world is that it's only guerrillas
paramilitaries and drugs but in reality
Colombia is the best in South America
South America Colombia he's thrilled
that tourism is increasing around san
agustin since 2002 foreign visitors to
the park have increased nearly tenfold
while tourism is a new industry
processing sugarcane
into bricks of unrefined sugar called
Cannella goes back centuries for many
years now Aniela
has been the staple of small farmers
diets whole area that's touching either
side of the room with it for my second
week I met up with two highschool
friends John and Doug we headed
northeast to body Chadha where queen
ants are on the menu all right so here's
the deal we are ready to knowing the
local delicacy of godets
protein so we have a container of them
that we're now going to add to the trail
mix that we brought going on north and
south america I felt Lee together make
friends mix around in there mmm look at
you later
nearby Santino where Australian
jean-claude Hesse opened the first
hostel seven years ago back then no
tourists ever came the Sandhill so
people were so happy to see a foreigner
everyone and wanted to invite me into
their home's Sam Hill is called
Columbia's adventure tourism capital but
my friends were not quite adrenaline
junkies this is electrical lines but in
that was so true in California for you
to see we stuck mostly to hiking and
cable cars like this one down into the
chica Mucha Canyon all over the country
there's a sense among Colombians that
its tourism moment has arrived it's a
it's a great time to to came and take
another look and another perspective of
what Colombia is sadly I couldn't stay
any longer I've reached the end of the
South American leg of my journey and now
I'm off to Central America and Mexico
